ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] MIME properties instead +
ygData.msgSnippet: I thought you were advocating using a few general types like application/xml and then push the specifics into the representation using RDF etc. No? Subbu ...

Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] MIME properties instead +
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=343278744; y=DYglnq-rqsYFA3dhduvdgb3kQ95TvYJ0PgSuQhyjHmnBREQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: sallamar

I thought you were advocating using a few general types like  
application/xml and then push the specifics into the representation  
using RDF etc. No?

Subbu

On Dec 17, 2008, at 12:23 PM, Bill de hOra wrote:

> Subbu Allamaraju wrote:
>>
>> On Dec 17, 2008, at 9:59 AM, Bill de hOra wrote:
>>
>>> For RDF, OWL, KIF, etc you have options. The media type tells you  
>>> which
>>> inferencing engine* you can apply and therefor what assumptions  
>>> can be
>>> made about the data.
>>>
>>> For mixed formats like uF and html+rdfa, you're right.
>>
>>
>> But this model reduces the visibility uniform interface. Entity  
>> headers
>> like Content-Type should be sufficient to learn about how to  
>> process the
>> message. If this was not the case, what are media types for?
>>
>> In any case, what problem does pushing the assumptions about the data
>> from the media type into the representation solve?
>
> I'm, not sure what your point is; you seem to be agreeing with I'm  
> saying.
>
>> OTOH, giving all the assumptions a name (i.e media type) makes it  
>> easier
>> for the application to use the right processing engine.
>
> Here you lost me. Applications don't tend to use media types, I  
> think we
> all know this, and even if that changed, it's not clear at all to me
> what the media type is for html containing various uFs and chunks of
> RDFa. I've said this before - we don't like protocol tunneling but
> format tunneling seems just fine - if wasn't, RDFa wouldn't get  
> through
> the W3C without an architectural objection.
>
> Bill

---
